Your help would be very significant in giving him work tools to a man who is looking to support and generate quality of living to a home composed of his wife and 10 children.

loans.use: to start a business selling fruit and vegetables, he needs to buy a variety of vegetables and shelves.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Harouna  est le monsieur qui  tient le bélier  sur la photo.
Harouna est  un  malien  non scolarisé âgé de 38 ans, marié et  Père de 07 enfants, âgés de 1 à  18 ans dont 3  sont scolarisés. Sa femme est une ménagère.
 Harouna fait  l’élevage des béliers, Il prend le prêt avec le RMCR pour acheter  beaucoup  de béliers. Il s’approvisionne  dans  les foires environnantes  et revend  ses béliers  en ville, parfois il  exporte.  Il  a une expérience de 10 ans  d’activité.
 Avec le profit qu’il réalise il satisfait les  besoins de sa famille (habillement, santé et frais de scolarité). Il est souvent confronté à certaines difficultés (mort ou perte de béliers) et  aux  coûts  élevé  des frais de transport .Dans l’avenir Harouna  veut  un prêt  plus  élevé pour développer son  activité d’élevage .
texts.en:
Harouna is 38 years old and comes from Mali.  He didn't complete any schooling, and is seen in the photo holding a sheep.  Harouna is married and has seven children, aged between one and eighteen years old.  Three of his children attend school.  His wife looks after their house and he raises sheep.  He has ten years' experience in his business.

Harouna has requested this loan with the field partner, RMCR, to buy many sheep from the local fairs.  He will then resell the animals in town, sometimes he exports them.  His profits will pay for healthcare, schooling and clothing for his children.

Harouna often has to deal with problems such as the death or loss of an animal and very high transport costs.  In the future, Harouna would like to take a larger loan and develop his livestock business further.

loans.use: to buy sheep to raise and sell on.

loans.name: Sabaly Group

texts.fr:
Portant une tasse de piment en main, Rokia est une ménagère âgée de 38 ans qui réside au Mali. Très respecté dans son environnement, elle vit avec son mari cultivateur de son état et ses 6 enfants dont les âges  sont  compris entre 1 et  15. Deux  fréquentent  l’école. 
Dans l’avenir elle envisage de rebâtir sa maison et donner  à ses enfants une meilleure condition de vie.
Elle fait recours  au R.M.C.R   pour le financement de ses petites activités génératrices  de revenus qu’elle pratique depuis une quinzaine  d’année.
Ses prêts sont utilisés pour acheter  des  semences de :piments, oignons et tomates 
Elle s’approvisionne dans les marchés environnants et vend  sa  production  dans ces mêmes marchés.
Malgré quelques petits soucis par rapport au lieu (le terrain) où  elle  exerce  ses  activités, elle se réjouit du progrès qu’elle constate  dans  sa vie sur le plan  nutritionnel.
texts.en:
Holding a bowl of chillies in her hands, Rokia is a 38-year-old, housewife who lives in Mali.  She is well respected in her community, and lives with her husband, a farmer, and their six children, aged between one and fifteen years old.  Two of her children currently attend school.  In the future, Rokia would like to build a house and give her children better living conditions.

Rokia has requested a loan from the field partner, RMCR, to finance the money-making activities that she has undertaken for fifteen years.  She will buy seed to grow chillies, onions and tomatoes from local markets, and will then sell her produce at the same markets.  

Rokia is very happy with the improvements she has made to the quality of food for her family even though she still has some problems with the land she uses to grow this food.

loans.use: to buy seed to cultivate her land.

loans.name: Serah

texts.en:
Serah is 45 years old and she supports seven family members. She has been a farmer for the last 15 years, and the business earns her an income of KES 11,000 per month. 

Serah has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer for her farming activity so as to increase her farming produce and meet client needs. She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her children. 

Her hope is to be financially stable and expand her business sector.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer for her farming activity so as to increase her farming produce and meet client needs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a hard-working woman entrepreneur with two children.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock of household goods to sell.

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like buying and selling nipa roofing.

Elizabeth dreams that one day she will be able to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of household goods to sell

loans.name: Jaquilyn

texts.en:
Jaquilyn is 36 years old. With three children who are in school, Jaquilyn works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a grocery store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of grocery items to sell.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of grocery items to sell

loans.name: Benkadi I Group

texts.fr:
Tièmoko est celui qui tient la corde du bœuf  parmi les membres  du groupe.
Tièmoko est âgé  de  54 ans. Il a 8  enfants  à sa  charge  dont   4  écoliers.
Il  s’endette  auprès  de R.M.C.R  pour  faire  son  activité  qui est  l’embouche  des bœufs.                                                                                                                          Il est crédible  et  exemplaire.
Tièmoko  exerce  cette activité  depuis   quelques  années.  Il  s’approvisionne  dans  les  marchés  environnants. 
Après   quelques  mois  durant  lesquels  il  nourrit   et  soigne  les  bœufs,  il  les  revend   dans  les  mêmes  marchés   locaux. 
Cette  activité  permet  à Tièmoko  de  pouvoir payer les frais scolaires  de ses enfants qui fréquentent  l’école  et  d’améliorer  la  nourriture de  sa  famille.
texts.en:
Tièmoko is 54 years old and is responsible for eight children, four of whom attend school.  He is seen in the photo with the other members of the group, holding a cow.  

Tièmoko has requested a loan from the field partner, RMCR, to buy cows to raise and sell on.  He is an exemplary man and has been running this business for several years.  He buys his animals at a local market and then, some months later, he resells them at the same market.  His profits will pay for schooling for his children and improve the food he can afford for his family.

loans.use: to buy cows to fatten up before selling on.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy peanuts to sell.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is 58 years old and he supports seven family members. He has been a taxi driver for the last 20 years and the business earns him an income of KES 11,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase tires and fuel for his vehicle so as to offer better transportation services for his clients.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate his children. His hopes are to be financially stable and expand his business sector.

loans.use: to purchase tires and fuel for his vehicle

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy, 28 years old, supports four family members. She has been practicing small-scale farming for the last five years, earning an income of KES 14,000 per month. 

She has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to improve her farming through use of certified seeds, boosting productivity for more income so as to improve family living standards. 

She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan as well as educating her children . Her hope is to lead a financially stable life.

loans.use: To improve her farming through use of certified seeds, boosting productivity for more income so as to improve family living standards.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy certified seeds, fertilizers, and herbicides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and farm tools for use on his farm, and he hopes this will enable him to get more farm produce to sell, so as to be able to educate his children.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
In the Philippines, sari-sari stores are everywhere. A sari-sari (variety) store sells different kinds of products, such as biscuits, candies, canned goods, noodles, personal hygiene products, and the like, which are involved in every individual’s daily living. This is one of the most common businesses built by ordinary people since it provides commodities for people. 

With this fact, Susana was enticed to get in touch with this kind of craft. She is 45 years old, is married to Mario, a security guard, and is a resident of Batasan, Quezon City, Philippines. They work with determination to pursue the needs of their family. The income they get from the store helps them with their daily expenditures. 

However, the profits they get from the business are sometimes insufficient. It is because at times she finds it hard to maintain supplies of various products due to financial incapability. This is why she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan that she will utilize to buy additional merchandise for her inventory. With more products displayed in her store, she can increase her income. 

In due time, she hopes that she will progress and that her business will increase sales. Through this, she can earn and save money for another place where they can build her own branch someday, if God allows. She is very thankful and she prays for more blessings to come. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise for her inventory

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en: Immaculate is 43 years old and married with six children, all of whom attend school. She has been a food vendor in the markets of Kasese, Uganda for six years, and she does farming for additional income. Out of her income, she has managed to start up a retail shop of general merchandise. Immaculate hopes to expand her business and build a residential house for her children. However, lack of capital is a challenge to achieving her dream. She is requesting a loan to buy cement, sand, and iron sheets for her residential house.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, and iron sheets for her residential house.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
It all starts with a dream. 

Wanting to invest someday in a car, expand her business, and eventually gain respect, Luz, 49 years of age, is doing her very best to excel in her trade. 

Luz resides at Batasan, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Ramer, who is busy operating a buy-and-sell business. They have three kids. Currently, Luz is operating her direct-selling business. She is selling different kinds of products, specifically electronic materials. The profit they get from both the businesses covers their family expenses.

To further improve the business, Luz wants to ask for a 30,000 PHP loan which she will use for buying more products to sell associated with her inventory. With this, she can surely earn more income. Part of what she will gain, she will save for future investments and part will be used for their everyday living. 
 
You’ll be a great blessing in advance. Thanks for your heartfelt generosity and goodness. 

Luz meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more products  associated with her inventory to sell.

loans.name: Musaenda Group

texts.es:
Cierta comunidad veracruzana ubicada entre cerros, sembradíos de caña, arboles de hule, limonares, naranjos y árboles de frutas exóticas como la yaca, es el entorno del grupo Musaenda cuyos integrantes y actividades son: Leoba que vende servilletas y verduras; Pascuala, dulces; Liliana, comida; Margarita, tortillas; Antonia, ropa; Deysi, artículos de oro y plata; Senobia, cosméticos; María Salome, comida típica; Eva, ropa y comida; Bárbara, calzado por catálogo; Elvia, bisutería, ropa, recipientes y comida; Lizbeth, ropa por catálogo y Joel que da mantenimiento a equipos de cómputo. 
   Joel vive con sus padres, es soltero y tiene muchas metas en su vida. De lunes a viernes trabaja en la escuela primaria de una comunidad cercana, él se encarga de la administración del lugar. El gusto que tiene por la tecnología y las ganas de superarse lo llevaron a desempeñarse en su negocio, que es reparar y dar mantenimiento a equipos de cómputo. Él recuerda que hace 8 años compuso la primera computadora “la maquina estaba desahuciada, a mi cliente le habían dicho que ya no serviría y yo la compuse, desde entonces arreglo de 2 a 5 equipos por mes”.
   Él ha notado un avance progresivo en su actividad, gracias a las ganancias iniciará con la venta de artículos para computadoras, invertirá el préstamo en dispositivos USB, ventiladores, bocinas, toallas y protectores, puesto que son los artículos más solicitados por algunos de sus clientes.
   Con las ganancias obtenidas y su sueldo apoya a sus padres con los gastos de la casa, satisface sus gastos personales, e invierte en la compra de herramienta necesaria para continuar trabajando.
   Joel agradece infinitamente la oportunidad del préstamo, al igual que el grupo entero, pues su actividad incrementa y algunos miembros incluso han iniciado una nueva actividad.

*La fotografía fue tomada en el patio de Doña Leoba quien muestra las costuras que borda, Joel es el único hombre en el grupo.
texts.en:
The Musaenda group lives in a community in Vera Cruz that is located among hills, sugarcane fields, rubber trees, lemon groves, orange groves, and exotic fruit trees like ‘yaca’ [jackfruit].  The members of the group and their business activities are Leoba, who sells napkins and vegetables; Pascual, who sells candy; Liliana, who sells food; Margarita, who sells tortillas; Antonia, who sells clothes; Deysi, who sells gold and silver items; Senobia, who sells cosmetics; María Salome, who sells typical food; Eva, who sells clothes and food; Bárbara, who sells shoes by catalog; Elvia, who sells costume jewelry, containers, and food; Lizbeth, who sells by catalog; and Joel, who provides maintenance to computer equipment.

Joel lives with his parents, and he is single.  He has a lot of goals in his life.  From Monday to Friday he works at an elementary school in a nearby community.  He is in charge of the administration of the school.  The enjoyment that he gets from technology and the desire to improve himself led him to work in his business, which is repairing and maintaining computer equipment.  He remembers that eight years ago he repaired the first computer. “The machine was a lost cause.  They had told my customer that it would no longer work, and I fixed it.  From then on I fix between two to five computers a month”.

He has noticed progressive advancement in his business activity.  Thanks to his earnings, he will start selling items for computers.  He will use the loan to buy USB devices, fans, speakers, screen wipes, and screen protectors.  These are the items that are most requested by some of his customers.

With the profits that he gets and with his salary he supports his parents with the household expenses, pays for his personal expenses, and buys the tools needed to continue working.

Joel is eternally grateful for the opportunity of the loan just as the whole group is.  His business activity increases, and some of the members have started new business activities.

*The photo was taken on Leoba’s patio.  She is showing the items that she embroiders.  Joel is the only man in the group.

loans.use: to buy USB devices, fans, speakers, screen wipes, and screen protectors.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy another fridge to use to meet customer demand for cold soft drinks and water

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add to her stock of fresh vegetables

loans.name: Mabel María

texts.es: Mabel de  44 años es madre de tres hijos, dos de los cuales ya son mayores de edad, decidió  perseguir nuevas oportunidades que ayudaran al  mejoramiento de su calidad de vida a través  de un negocio que pudiera desarrollar desde su casa para no descuidar a su familia.  Ella siguió los pasos de una amiga que desde hace varios años se dedica a la venta por catálogos con muy buenos resultados. Gracias a las innumerables opciones de catálogos especializados que ofertan productos y artículos de uso personal de buena calidad y con precios acordes a la capacidad de pago de sus clientes, Mabel logró incorporarse al negocio y desde hace un año se dedica de lunes a domingo a  promover los catálogos entre vecinos y conocidos  para  lograr la meta de ventas de sus productos, los cuales cancela de contado; sin embargo ella les ofrece a sus clientes facilidad de pago para lo cual requiere de una mayor inversión y por lo tanto está aplicando para su primer CrediKiva con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, que invertirá en la compra de ropa y artículos para el hogar. Ella sueña con organizar un local comercial donde pueda exhibir sus productos y tener el reconocimiento de sus clientes para lo cual le apuesta a su perseverancia y deseos de crecer.
texts.en: Mabel, 44, is the mother of three, two of her children are grown. She decided to pursue new opportunities to improve her quality of life, through a business which she could run out of her home so she would not neglect her family. She followed a friend's example who had been working in catalog sales for several years with very good results. Thanks to the countless specialty catalogs available that offer personal products of high quality at affordable prices, Mabel managed to launch her business. For the past year, she has worked Monday through Sunday promoting the catalogs to neighbors and acquaintances selling products, which are cash sales. Still, she offers her customers easy payment options, which requires a larger investment, so she is applying for her first CrediKiva with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, which she will use to buy clothing and household items. Her dream is to open a shop where she can display her products and be recognized by her customers; she channels her perseverance and desire for growth towards this goal.

loans.use: to buy clothing and household items

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy meat for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fruits to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more cereal grains to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 48 years old and married to Josephine. He supports five family members. He has been a farmer for the last 18 years, and the business earns him an income of KES 12,000 per month.

James has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase farm tools, such as jembes for ploughing his farm, to eliminate weeds that compete for nutrients for a better farm product for sale in the market.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate his children.

His hope is to be financially stable and to expand his agricultural sector.

loans.use: to purchase farm tools, such as jembes for ploughing his farm, to eliminate weeds that compete for nutrients for a better farm product for sale in the market.

loans.name: Júpiter Group

texts.es:
En cierta comunidad oaxaqueña se resguarda el patrimonio de la cultura mazateca ya que 30% de sus habitantes aún hablan su lengua materna además de que continúan festejando tradiciones y elaborando sus artesanías más representativas. La laguna local es un importante atractivo turístico por lo que representa una gran fuente de empleo para los lugareños quienes han establecido negocios de comida a orillas de la misma. Los platillos principales se preparan con la mojarra, pez típico de la región. 
   El grupo Júpiter es originario de la comunidad  y está conformado por ocho personas cuyos nombres y actividades son: Norma quien vende ropa; Gaudencia, cosméticos; Brigida, manteles, servilletas y ropa; Ofelia y Simona, pescado; Esperanza, refresco; Petra, cosméticos y Cecilia quien se dedica a la costura. 
   Doña Cecilia es una mujer emprendedora, y comprometida con su familia, está casada con el señor Demetrio con quien tiene cuatro hijos, los dos más pequeños continúan estudiando.  
   Desde la edad de ocho años, Doña Cecilia se ha dedicado a la costura. En un inicio realizaba la actividad completamente a mano, para ello utilizaba aguja e hilo únicamente, “un día mis padres salieron al campo, fui al ropero, tomé una sábana floreada nueva; corté la tela y me apresuré a cocerla. Cuando mis padres regresaron me escondí, al escuchar la  reacción de mi madre al ver lo que hice no quería salir” sonríe mientras recuerda aquellos años en los que su inquietud ya se dejaba ver. Tiempo después ya se encargaba de elaborar la ropa de sus hermanas y más tarde consiguió su primera máquina de coser, herramienta importante para su actividad.
   Hoy en día Cecilia es una costurera certificada que incluso imparte talleres en un instituto del municipio. Con sus ganancias ha logrado comprar ocho maquinas más, dos de ellas industriales. “Mi mayor anhelo es adquirir dos máquinas para bordado y contratar a algunas personas en la comunidad”. El préstamo lo invertirá en tela, hilos, botones y agujas pues le han solicitado muchos uniformes para clausuras escolares que ya se aproximan.
  
*En la fotografía Doña Cecilia es quien viste blusa color amarillo y porta lentes.
texts.en:
In the community of Oaxaqueña, Mazatec cultural heritage is protected since 30% of its inhabitants still speak their mother tongue, in addition they continue to celebrate traditions and produce representative handicrafts. The local lake is an important tourist attraction and for this reason it is a great source of employment for the locals who have established food businesses on its banks. The main dishes are prepared with 'mojarra', a type of sea bream which is typical of the region. 

The Júpiter group comes from this community and is composed of 8 members whose names and professions are: Norma who sells clothes; Gaudencia, cosmetics; Brigida, tablecloths, napkins and clothes; Ofelia and Simona, fish; Esperanza, soft-drinks; Petra, cosmetics and Cecilia who makes a living dressmaking.

Cecilia is an enterprising woman who is committed to her family. She is married to Demitrio and they have four children together, the two youngest are still in school. Cecilia has been sewing ever since the age of eight. In the beginning she did all of her needlework by hand and used a needle and thread only. She says “one day my parents went off out to the field. I went into the wardrobe and took out a new flowery sheet; I cut the fabric and hurried myself to sew it back together again. When my parents returned I hid, and upon hearing my mother’s reaction when she saw what I did, I didn’t want to come out again”. Cecilia smiles as she remembers those years in which she was so curious. Thereafter, she was in charge of making clothes for her sisters and later she got her first sewing machine, an important tool for her business.

Today, Celia is a certified seamstress who even teaches workshops at an institute in the town. With her earnings she has managed to buy eight more machines, two of which are industrial ones. “My greatest desire to is to purchase two embroidery machines and to hire some people from the local community”. The loan will be invested in cloth, thread, buttons and needles because they have been asked to make a large quantity of uniforms for the school closures that are coming up.
 
Cecilia is pictured wearing a yellow blouse and is wearing glasses.

loans.use: to buy cloth, thread, buttons and needles.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a bull for slaughter so as to sell meat to his clients and meet their needs and those of his family.

loans.name: Linneth

texts.en: Linneth is 31 years old, married to Josephat and she supports 6 family members. She has been a farmer for the last 4 years now and the business earns her an income of KES 10,000 per month. She has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase fertilizer for topdressing her crops so as to get a better harvest. She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay this loan as well as to educate her children. Her hope is to be financially stable and start a retail shop.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for topdressing her crops so as to get a better harvest

loans.name: Cleta

texts.en:
Cleta is 49 years old and married with one child. She works very hard to provide for her family.

She runs a buy-and-sell dried fish and cashew nut business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks of dried fish and cashew nuts to sell. Cleta has been in this business for six years.

In the future, Cleta would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of dried fish and cashew nuts to sell

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is a 26-year-old Lebanese married woman who lives with her husband and two children. She has worked as a private teacher since 2014. She equipped a room in her house with all the needed details in order to receive her students. She likes her occupation so much because she likes to help students to get the right education. She receives students in her house and also visits some at their places.

To better advance her profession, today she is requesting to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to buy a new car so as to facilitate her work. In the future, she wishes to receive more students with the new coming year.

loans.use: to buy a new car

loans.name: Vivencia

texts.en:
Vivencia is a 48-year-old entrepreneur from Ubay, Bohol. She is married with six children, three of whom are still dependents, aged 10, 13 and 15.

Vivencia operates a sari-sari (general) store where she sell noodles, vinegar, seasoning, chips, bleaching agent, salted beans, biscuits and toiletries. She is asking for a loan to buy liquors, cigarettes and soft drinks. This will help increase her sales.

In the future, she hopes to see all her children become professionals and her business become more stable than it is now.

loans.use: to buy liquors, cigarettes and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy dairy feeds for her dairy cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional stocks of fresh fruits in season especially oranges, bananas and pears.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy timbers for use in his work for more income gain.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and dairy feed; she hopes this will enable her to get more milk to sell and make more income to support her family.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida has been working as a seamstress for 18 years now in a garment factory in Cavite through the auspices of the CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative*.

Adelaida does the sewing and designing of clothing apparel according to the company or the client’s demand. She sews clothes using a sewing machine or other stitching machines, or often does hand stitching of edges and linings.

One of the main dilemmas of employees, like Adelaida, is the improper balancing of their salaries with family expenses, and they have no access to savings or credit, a situation that made them heavily indebted to usurious money lenders who captured their automated teller machine (ATM) cards as loan collateral. 

For this reason, Adelaida is asking for your assistance to prevent her from being exposed to loan sharks. She has also previously accessed loans through CCT Credit Cooperative and she had no problem in repaying since the loan payment is being deducted every payday.  Adelaida looks forward for your positive response and any coming amount from you will surely be of great help. She will also use the loan to pay for their housing expense.

Adelaida hopes to improve their present financial condition. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work. 

* The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for deployment in construction and site development projects.  The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, quality for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families.  Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services.

** CCT staff and volunteers regularly conducts fellowship meeting for the factory workers before starting their daily work routine. Bible readings, prayer devotions and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and post-working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: To pay for their housing expense.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn works hard to support her family. Evelyn is married and has a buy-and-sell rice business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to purchase an additional sack of rice to sell.

Evelyn has been in this business for years now.

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase an additional sack of rice to sell

loans.name: Iluminda

texts.en:
Iluminda is 53 years old and married with six children, two of whom are in school. Iluminda works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, soft drinks, coffee, sugar, eggs, etc.

Iluminda has been in this business for five years.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, soft drinks, coffee, sugar, eggs, etc

loans.name: Enos

texts.en: Enos is a married father of  four children living in Hoima-Uganda. His business is selling motorcycle spare parts. He also does fish sellling for extra income. He started his business in 2010 to earn income to support his family. His personal goal is to have all his children educated. His business goal to explore the available markets to full capacity and increase his earnings. However, weather changes and high taxes on fish dealers affect his business. Enos is requesting for a loan to buy fish and fish powder for selling.

loans.use: to buy fish and fish powder for selling.

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en: Innocent is a 28-year-old married father of one child living in Hoima, Uganda. Innocent is a farmer who mainly grows maize for commercial purposes. To supplement his income, he earns a monthly salary from a micro finance institution. His business is affected by limited capital on top of seasonal changes. Innocent intends to use the loan to buy farm inputs like manure and fertilizer to increase soil productivity.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs like manure and fertilizer to increase soil productivity.

loans.name: Tenda Sasa Group

texts.en:
Mazambi (far right), sells clothing and fabric for a living. 

With her new loan, she would like to buy more panges of material to sell, a Congolese staple. 

The last loan increased her profits and she wants to continue that trend so she can better provide for her family.

loans.use: To buy more fabric to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and farming tools for use on her farm

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
She is Maricel, whose previous loan was a big help for their household expenses. She was also able to provide assistance for her aging mother.

Maricel is requesting another 9,000 PHP loan for the transportation allowance of her family who wants to take a vacation in the province. She also wants to spend the remaining weeks of summer with family before going again to work and busy schedules. 

She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Maricel wishes to give all the best for her family, especially for her children. She wants for them to finish their studies in the future and she aims to build their own house someday. She consistently meets up with her co-workers to share stories of her life and business every day before starting their work, and finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

loans.use: To be used by her family's transportation allowance who will spend their vacation in the province.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan, a father of two children, is a resident of Hoima, Uganda. He deals in the selling of second-hand clothes and gets additional income from agriculture. He got involved in the above businesses with the aim of getting income to sustain and educate his children. He is a hardworking man who dreams of growing his business to have a permanent location and also adding on selling shoes that his customers ask for. 

Despite his dreams, Allan is challenged by inadequate capital and too much sunshine, as he works from an open space. Allan intends to use the loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente is a 34-year-old production worker of a garment factory in Carmona Cavite, Philippines. He already has two children and is married to Desire, who is also a factory worker. They are both beneficiaries of the employment services under the supervision of CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative*.

Vicente works as a clothing presser.  He presses fabrics or garments during the production process (known as under-pressing), as well in the final stages of production (usually in a garment-finishing department).

One of the main dilemmas of employees, like Vicente, is the improper balancing of their salaries with family expenses and they have no access to savings or credit, a situation that made them heavily indebted to usurious money lenders who captured their automated teller machine (ATM) cards as loan collateral. 

For this reason, Vicente is asking for your assistance to prevent him from being exposed to any loan sharks. He has also previously accessed loans through CCT Credit Cooperative and he had no problem in returning it back since the loan payment is being deducted every pay day.  He looks forward for your positive response and any help from you will surely be of great help. He will use the loan to redeem their rights for their forfeited house.

Vicente dreams to improve their present living condition. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work. 

* The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for deployment in construction and site development projects.  The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, quality for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families.  Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services.

** CCT staff and volunteers regularly conducts fellowship meeting for the factory workers before starting their daily work routine. Bible readings, prayer devotions and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre and post working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: To redeem their rights for their forfeited house.

loans.name: Glorious

texts.en: Glorious owns s a retail shop that sells general merchandise and she lives in Hoima, Uganda. She has been in business for the last two years. She started business upon realizing that there was a readily available market in her area that was lacking such services. She has a business dream of expanding her business into a wholesale operation but is limited by capital inadequacy and competition. She also dreams of educating her children and buying a plot of land to construct rentals for them. Glorious is in need of a loan to buy stock like paraffin, cooking oil, soap and other items to sell.

loans.use: to buy stock like paraffin, cooking oil, soap and other items to sell.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a hardworking man who runs a retail shop that sells general merchandise. He does farming so as to boost his income. He lives in Masindi-Uganda with his four children and three are able to attend school. He started the business so as to cater for his family needs. He desires to educate his children, though inadequate capital affects his cash flow.

He is requesting a loan to buy general merchandise like soap, sugar and salt.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise like soap, sugar and salt.

loans.name: Kanara Bakyara Twimukye Group

texts.en:
Jane is a hardworking, married woman living in Kamwenge, Uganda. She is a member of Kanara Bakyara Twimukye Group, a women's group. 

She has 4 children and they all attend school. She operates a local restaurant and does crop farming to supplement her income. This has enabled her to pay school fees for her children and cater for her family's needs. She wishes to have a big business and educate all her children but is limited by challenges such as poor seasons and price fluctuation of agricultural produce. 

She is in a group where members guarantee each other to obtain a loan. Jane is requesting a loan to buy more fresh food and hotel equipment for her restaurant.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food and hotel equipment for her restaurant.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a hardworking married man who lives in Masindi, Uganda. He sells produce such as groundnuts, beans, rice and other things. He also does farming and runs a bar to supplement his income. 

He hopes to buy a personal car to ensure that he perfects his service delivery on time. However, weather and droughts affect his business.

Patrick is requesting a loan to buy more cereals like maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy more produce like maize to sell.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana, who is a 29-year-old married woman, lives in Rustavi city. She has a little son and a mother-in-law, who works at the railway and gets a fixed salary. Diana gets small transfers from abroad which her husband sends to her. 

In order to have her own business and generate the income, Diana opened a restaurant locally with the saved money. Now she needs financial support to purchase an additional stock of food products and have money for working capital. She quite well developed the business and equipped her restaurant for all the needed tools and furniture. 

Diana received the credit in the framework of a joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Startup Program that gives people the chance to start or re-start businesses. 

She is a very hard-working and motivated woman, with a great desire to make a good style of life for her family members and also develop her business activity. 

Diana will be very grateful for giving the chance to increase the productivity and will highly appreciate Kiva lenders help and kindness.

loans.use: To purchase an additional stock of food products for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy additonal clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy equipment, injections and medicines for her husband's medical clinic.

loans.name: Makimbilio Group

texts.en:
The Makimbilio Group is made up of five women who all live in the same neighborhood and work as retailers. This is their second loan from Wezesha project.
Kasuku is the group's representative and she is on the left in the photo. She is a married mother of five children. She has been selling fuel for three years. Kasuku will use her loan to buy more fuel to sell. Kasuku's greatest wish is to be a wholesaler and expand her business so that she can increase her savings and think about buying her own home.

loans.use: to buy fuel

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy and build a bathroom at their home to improve their access to water and sanitation.

loans.name: Marian

texts.en:
Much thanks to you, kind-hearted lenders! Because of your previous support, Marian has already redeemed her ATM card and was able to pay for the educational expenses of their children. She's very appreciative and wishes you more blessings!

This time, she's seeking your help once again as she's longing to repair their house that is already wearing away. They can now provide for their basic needs such as food, utilities and education. However, house repair and improvement lag behind other priorities. With a lot of typhoons that swept the Philippines, their house has been deteriorating. Much as they want to restore and improve it, they don’t want to snatch the budget for their basic needs and children’s education. We're praying that with your kind help she can now have the opportunity to restore and improve their house, a home for their happy family.  

Marian dreams for their children to finish education as it is their most valued inheritance. With a college degree, they have a better chance to remove themselves from poverty. She continuously meets up with her co-fellowship members in the Covenant Community Service Cooperative to inspire and strengthen each other.

loans.use: to pay for house repair and improvements.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
This is Teddy, from Carmona, Cavite, who has been employed at a garment factory in GMA, Cavite for fourteen years now. He works there as Packer who prepares the finished products for shipping or delivery. Sometimes he does the repacking in case there are mistakes in terms of quantity and quality of packaging.

Just recently he got married to Myra, and their first child is on the way. He is quite excited at the arrival of their firstborn and he is preparing for his wife's delivery. Although he already has some savings, he still needs huge amount. As a single person before, he has this loving attitude of giving a large portion of his salary to his parents to help in their everyday needs. Only a meager portion was being left for his allowance and savings. This is very usual for Filipino families who are known to be so closely knit. Teddy consulted his co-fellowship** members at CCT Covenant Community Service Cooperative* regarding his impending needs for his wife’s delivery. He was advised to avoid those usurious money-lending agencies that proliferate in their community and he was offered another option through YOU. The entire cooperative is praying for your help and for the safe delivery of their child.

Teddy dreams of running a business someday and he is quite positive that it will help his family experience a more abundant life. When that time comes, he would be happy to help other people in need. 

*The Covenant Community Service Cooperative works to provide local communities with a labor force trained and equipped with the skills required for employment. The cooperative prepares its members to acquire these skills, qualify for jobs, cultivate savings consciousness, and provide decent shelter, food, and education for their families. Its core programs are the following: Professional Staff Services Program, Workers Guild Development Program, Enterprise Development Program, and Consultancy Services. **CCT staff and volunteers regularly conduct fellowship meetings for the factory workers before they start their daily work routines. Bible readings, prayer devotions, and spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and post-working hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: to pay for his wife's delivery of their child.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en: Bernadette works hard to support her family. Bernadette is married and has a buy-and-sell rice business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 18000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice for resale. Bernadette has been in this business for 10 years now. In the future, Bernadette would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice for resale

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en:
Priscilla is 56 years old with 6 children and is a hardworking entrepreneur. Priscilla operates her laundry business from her former job as a laundress. She started with 1 washing machine and does the laundry herself. The location of her business is near to the school and dormitories, which is good for her laundry business.

Over time, she was able to purchase 4 more washing machines and to have 2 helpers. Through her business, she was able to finance her children's education and to help her 2 helpers' children to also have an education through scholarships.

Priscilla still has 2 more children in college and still wants to improve her business in order to help more with their expenses.

Priscilla is requesting a loan amounting to PhP 30,000 to repair 2 washing machines and dryers to be used for business, especially now that the school year is beginning.

Priscilla goal is to improve her business by giving the best and fastest service in doing laundry for the students to gain more customers and increase her income.

loans.use: to repair 2 washing machines and dryers for use in business

loans.name: Tariel

texts.en:
Tariel is 53 years old and divorced. He lives alone in the village of Salominao. Tariel earns a living by cultivating a plot of land. He grows maize and also has nut trees, selling the nuts and maize at the local market. As he has only seasonal income, Tariel decided to start dairy farming. He sought credit from local financial institutions, but his attempts were unsuccessful because of his poor living conditions. The startup program, a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, enables rural poor people to get a loan for starting or re-starting businesses. His application was approved under the framework of this program for a loan of 1,600 GEL for purchasing two milking cows. After the cows are purchased, Tariel will start producing dairy products, such as cheese and yogurt, for selling. 
The loan will greatly assist Tariel and he will be able to improve his economic situation and expand his agribusiness in the future.

loans.use: To purchase two milking cows and start dairy farming

loans.name: Jibu Kwa Wanyonge Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Jibu Kwa Wanyonge Group, The group is made up of five members who are borrowing from Wezesha Project.
This loan will help their small business, including Nsimire's. This is her sixth loan from Wezesha Project, having initially joined at a friend's invitation.
Nsimire has a business selling groundnuts and beans  She started this business with a little bit of capital.
She will use the money from this loan as working capital to buy more groundnuts to sell. This will allow her to generate income to support her family. In the photo, Nsimire is the tallest. She is married and has five children.

loans.use: to purchase groundnuts.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more calabashes (gourds)

loans.name: Maridel

texts.en:
From Laguna, Philippines, Maridel is a 43-year-old widow who is working in garment factory in Cavite through the auspices of the Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT). She does the sewing and stitching of different apparels according to the company or client’s dictates. She uses a sewing machine and other stitching machines as well as handstitching hems and linings.

One of the main dilemmas of employees like Maridel is meeting family expenses without access to savings or credit. Workers can become heavily indebted to money lenders who take their ATM cards as loan collateral. 

For this reason, Maridel would like to ask for your assistance to help her circumvent loan sharks. She has previously accessed loans through CCT and had no problem in repaying them since the loan payments were automatically deducted from her paycheck. She is seeking an 8,000 PHP loan to pay for roof installation cost of their house.

She looks forward to your positive response and says any amount will surely be of great help. Maridel hopes that her child will finish her education with flying colors.

CCT works to provide local communities with a trained labor force and equipped with the skills required for employment in construction and site development projects. The cooperative assists its members in acquiring those skills necessary for quality jobs, cultivating savings consciousness and providing decent shelter, food, and education for their families. Its core programs include Professional Staff Services, Workers Guild Development, Enterprise Development and Consultancy Services.

CCT staff and volunteers regularly conduct fellowship meetings for factory workers before starting their daily work routine. Bible readings, prayer devotions, spiritual mentoring and discipleship sessions take place during pre- and after-work hours and breaks, powering up the lives of both volunteer leaders and line workers.

loans.use: to pay for the roof installation cost of their house.

loans.name: Ederlinda

texts.en: Ederlinda is married with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Ederlinda is 60 years old and has one child who is in school. She has a fishing business in the Philippines. Ederlinda has requested a PHP 15000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional fishing nets. Ederlinda has been in this business for years now. In the future, Ederlinda would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing nets

loans.name: Shukurani Group

texts.en:
Kituza (second from left) works hard to provide for her children through her small shop. 

She will use this new loan to purchase sugar, eggs, and other items in her shop. 

This loan will propel her small shop ahead and allow her to generate more income that will enable her to take care of her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional items such as soft drinks, sugar, eggs, and other goods.

loans.name: Luz De Alba

texts.en:
Luz  is a working mom who lives in Tabasco with her family. Every morning Luz wakes up at dawn to go to work so she can save enough to put a roof over her children’s heads. 

Together with her husband she make around USD 12,000 a year and finally after years of hard work and saving as much as they can they can finish working on their home so their children can grow up in a homey and safe environment. 

Luz and her husband started building the foundation of their home but soon realized that the house was going to cost more than expected and that they needed some guidance because big mistakes were costing them money. 

However, they need this loan to start building right away, and she can complete paying for all the materials necessary to continue the building process. Luz and her husband will work on the construction of their home along with certified technicians who will provide all the assistance and support needed to make sure their new home meets all the safety and quality standards.

loans.use: to buy materials to finish building her house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a rickshaw for her husband to drive to make money in the evening.

loans.name: Tunda La Roho Group

texts.en:
This will be the third loan for Matisho of the Wezesha Project group, Tunda la Roho. 

She is requesting her loan to purchase more eggs to sell and to increase her profits. This will allow her to better provide for her family. 

All members of the group said that the last loan helped them increase their stocks and profits, so they have requested another.

loans.use: to purchase more eggs to sell

loans.name: Yorledys Yolanda

texts.es: Yorledys es una mujer emprendedora de 33 años que desde muy joven se dedicó al comercio a través de la venta directa por catálogos. Esta gran emprendedora cuenta que siempre sostuvo cosas esenciales en la atención al cliente: la manera de llegarle a la gente y satisfacer sus necesidades. Esta actividad que realiza de lunes a sábado entre su clientela conformada por amigos, vecinos y familiares. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para invertir en artículos para el hogar; planchas, licuadoras, tendidos y demás.  Esta inversión le permitirá incrementar el stock de productos, con estrategias de ventas  definidas en cuanto a precios, calidad y cantidad y otros aspectos  que generen el reconocimiento del cliente, pues ella dice que lo mas gratificante es el buen servicio y la satisfacción de continuar apoyando a su cónyuge con la economía de su casa,  para sacar adelante la educación de su pequeña de tres años.
texts.en:
Yorledys, 33, is an enterprising woman who has made a living buying and selling merchandise since she was a girl.  She buys merchandise from catalogs and resells what she buys to her customers.  She keeps supplies of products so that she can deliver what her customers want when they want it.  Most of her customers are friends and neighbors and she works from Mondays to Saturdays.  
Yorledys is applying to Kiva's partner, Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, for a loan that she will use to stock irons, blenders, drying racks and other housekeeping products.  The investment will allow her to supply the products that her buyers want at a reasonable price.  Meeting that demand, she says, is immensely satisfying for her.  She is also pleased that she can help her husband with the family's expenses and save for her three-year old daughter's education.

loans.use: to stock irons, blenders, and other housekeeping products for her retail sales business.

loans.name: Manuel Alexander

texts.es: Manuel vive con su madre y su abuelita  en una casa muy humilde y comenta que es su madre  quien le enseña al negocio de crianza de animales menores, Manuel comenta que desde que termino la secundaria se dedica a trabajar de ayudante de albañil, ya que no tiene los recursos económicos necesarios para seguir estudiando. Manuel solicita el dinero del crédito para invertirlo en la compra de pollos para tenerlos en un corral, la aspiración de Manuel es la de seguir en su negocio y en su trabajo, para apoyar a su madre en los gastos del hogar asi como lo ha venido haciendo hasta ahora, pero la mayor meta de Manuel es la de poder entrar a estudiar aunque sea a distancia.
texts.en:
Manuel lives in a very humble house with his mother and grandmother. He says that his mother is teaching him the business of raising small animals.

Manuel says that he has been working as a bricklayer's assistant since he finished high school because he lacks the financial means to continue his education.

He is requesting a loan to buy chickens to raise.

Manuel plans to continue with the business and keep his job to help his mother cover the household expenses, as he has been doing so far. However, his biggest goal is to continue studying, even if it is through distance education.

loans.use: to buy chickens.

loans.name: Revazi

texts.en:
Revazi is a 60-year-old man from Khobi District. He lives alone and earns a living with a small agricultural business. Revazi cultivates a plot of land, where he harvests nuts and laurel. He also breeds one milk cow and produces milk products for local selling. 

Revazi decided to expand his agribusiness and seek credit among local financial institutions, but his attempts was unsuccessful because of his poor living conditions. The start-up program, which is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, enables the rural poor to access loans for starting or re-starting businesses. His application was approved under the framework of this program. His loan of 2,000 GEL will be used to purchase seeds of beans and cultivate the land. 

He is a very enthusiastic and hardworking person with a great desire to achieve financial stability and increased income. This credit will be a great support for him. Revazi is thankful to Kiva lenders for giving him a chance to generate additional income.

loans.use: To purchase seeds of beans and cultivate the land

loans.name: Sagrado Corazón Group

texts.es:
El grupo Sagrado Corazón se conformó en una comunidad destacada por ser de las tres primeras en la producción de azúcar. Durante el recorrido para llegar al lugar se aprecian cañales e ingenios que son fábricas donde se procesa la caña para obtener el azúcar en grano o liquida. Las integrantes del grupo son: Delfina que vende ropa; María, calzado; Shely, artículos de acero y oro laminado; Virginia, hamacas. Por su parte Paula tiene una papelería mientras que Mayra y Alma tienen un centro de cómputo. 
   La señora Virginia es una mujer muy comprometida con su familia y consigo misma. Jamás ha dejado de trabajar. Desde hace siete años que llegó a radicar a la comunidad, se ha dedicado a la elaboración y venta de hamacas, catres y sillones tejidos con hilo. “Aprendí a tejer las hamacas en el reclusorio en conjunto con los presos, también aprendí a tejer los catres y sillones” comenta entusiasmada. Virginia visitaba a un familiar en el reclusorio y aprovechaba el tiempo para aprender de los presos y enseñar a otros lo que ya sabía. Para la elaboración de sus productos compra hilo en grandes cantidades que consigue en Chiapas a un mejor precio puesto que los proveedores le conocen por ser originaria de ese estado.
   Virginia se siente orgullosa con el resultado de su trabajo “Las hamacas son fáciles de transportar, el cliente suele relajarse al acostarse en ellas, si bien no muchos valoran el trabajo, hay quienes si tienen aprecio y respeto por las artesanías que elaboramos”. 
   Con los préstamos otorgados y parte de las ganancias obtenidas apoya a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y reinvertirá en la materia prima. Esta vez el préstamo lo utilizara para comprar hilo y guarda cabos para ofrecer con ellos una mayor durabilidad a los brazos de las hamacas.
   El grupo Sagrado Corazón agradece a VisionFund por los préstamos otorgados ya que con ellos se ha logrado el crecimiento de las actividades.

*La fotografía fue tomada en el centro de cómputo de Alma, Doña Virginia es quien viste blusa color rosa, está junto a Doña Rufina quien viste pantalón color amarillo.
texts.en:
The Sagrado Corazón group was formed in a community noted for being one of the three large sugar producers. On the ride to get to this place you see the sugar cane and mills which are factories where they process the cane to obtain liquid or grains of sugar.

The members of the group are: María, footwear; Shely, steel and gold plated items; Virginia, hammocks. For her part Paula has a stationary store while Mayra and Alma have an internet cafe.

Virginia is very committed to her family and to herself. She has never stopped working. For the 7 years she has lived in this community she has worked making and selling hammocks, cots and chairs with thread. "I learned how to weave the hammocks in prison along with the prisoners and I also learned how to weave the cots and chairs" she comments with enthusiasm. Virginia visited a family member in prison and took advantage of the time to learn from the prisoners and teach others what she knows.

To make the products she buys thread in great quantities that she buys in Chiapas at a good price given that the distributors know her s she is a native of this state. Virginia feels proud of the results of her work. " The hammocks are easy to transport, clients relax lying in them and if it is not a lot of work, people appreciate and respect the artisans that make them".

With the loans received and part of her profits she supports her husband with the household expenses and reinvests in raw material. This time she will use the loan to buy thread and thimbles to provide more durability to the arms of the hammock.

The Sagrado Corazon group is grateful to VisionFund for the loans awarded as with it they have been able to expand their businesses. the photograph was taken in Alma's internet cafe. Virginia is wearing the pink colored blouse beside Rufina who is wearing the yellow pants.

loans.use: to buy thread and thimbles.

loans.name: Maria Dolores

texts.en:
Maria Dolores works in the city cleaning houses. She is a hardworking mother of three and loving wife living in Tabasco. She works from dawn until dusk from Monday to Friday in order to make some money and give her family a better life. 

Maria Dolores and her family have been living in their house for some time. They have been saving for some time to finish some work they started a while ago but ran out of resources to complete. To Maria Dolores, giving every opportunity to her children is very important. She only had the opportunity to study until elementary school and is convinced that giving more education and better opportunities to her children will definitely give them a better life. 

Maria Dolores and her husband have informal jobs, thus accessing credit from other financial institutions is almost impossible. Maria Dolores is asking for this loan to complete the payment for materials needed for the construction. With this loan, she will also receive technical assistance and supervision to make sure that the construction will comply with all the safety and quality standards.

loans.use: to buy materials to finish building her house

loans.name: Huayacan Group

texts.es:
La comunidad de donde proviene el grupo Huayacan es reconocida por su producción de caña. Se encuentra a un costado de la carretera que conduce a un importante centro turístico dentro del estado de Veracruz.
   Para los integrantes de Huayacan el nombre es exótico, original y único, justo como ellos. Sus actividades son: Delfino quien vende fertilizantes; Irene, antojitos típicos; Irma, Eva y Clara, abarrotes; Eustaquio, verdulería; Odilia, refrescos; Ana, pollo; Sara, ropa; Agripina, cerdos y Leticia, zapatos.
    Doña Irma es madre de tres mujeres y dos hombres todos ellos mayores de edad, actualmente la menor de sus hijas vive con ella.  Desde hace diez años, después de enviudar, decidió iniciar con una pequeña tienda de abarrotes la cual abrió con los ahorros que guardaba, de tal manera que ahora genera sus propios ingresos.  "En la tienda invierto mi tiempo libre, obtengo mis propias ganancias y no dependo de nadie”.  La tienda, además, le sirve como terapia para no sentirse sola pues comenta que brinda servicio a partir de las 5:00 am. Los clientes buscan desde muy temprano la variedad que ofrece Doña Irma en su negocio. Exhibe la mercancía en anaqueles metálicos donde el cliente puede señalar el producto que desean adquirir.
   Con las ganancias obtenidas ha solventado los gastos del hogar, reinvierte en la compra de mercancía, sobre todo frijol, arroz, azúcar, huevos, aceite, queso, galletas y café que son los productos más solicitados. Los planes de doña Irma son integrar la venta de verduras para brindar variedad a sus clientes, por lo cual está vez el préstamo lo  invertirá en chile, jitomate, cebolla, ajo además de arroz, frijol, aceite y papel higiénico. Otra meta que tiene es crear su propio fondo de ahorro.
   El grupo agradece a cada una de las personas que ha hecho posible la oportunidad del préstamo con lo que hacen crecer su actividad.

*La fotografía fue tomada en la comunidad, Doña Irma es quien viste blusa color morado.
texts.en:
The Huayacan community bank meets in a rural area known for caña production.  Their town is along a highway that leads to an important tourist area in the state of Veracruz.  For the group's members, Huayacan is an unique and exotic name, just like them.  
The members and their businesses are: Delfino, fertilizer sales; Irene, prepared food sales; Irma, Eva and Clara, corner groceries; Eustaquio, vegetable sales; Odilia, soft drink sales; Ana, poultry sales; Sara, clothing sales; Agripina, animal sales; and Leticia, footwear sales.  
Doña Irma has three daughters and two sons, all grown.  (One daughter still lives with her.)  She has operated a grocery business for 10 years, a business that she started after she was widowed.  She opened the grocery with her savings and it is now her means of supporting herself.  "I work at the store, earn my own way and don't depend on anyone else for my living", she says.  The business is a sort of therapy, she adds, because there are always people around and she is never lonely.  She opens the store at 5:00am because her customers often come very early to buy from her.  She stocks her merchandise on metal shelves and her customers tell her what they want.  Her income from the business covers her expenses.
Doña Irma has reinvested part of her earnings to stock her business with beans, rice, sugar, eggs, cooking oil, cheese, coffee and snacks because those are the products that her customers most want.  She will use her share of the loan to add new products so that her customers have a wider range of goods to buy: chiles, jitomates, onions, garlic, and toilet paper, for example.  She also wants to create a pool of savings that she can draw on in future.  
The members of the group want you to know that they are grateful for the opportunities that your loans give them.  

* Doña Irma is pictured in the photo wearing a purple blouse.

loans.use: to stock merchandise that she will resell.

location.town: Localidad Santo Domingo, Mun. Tres Valles Veracruz

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer for use on his farm; he hopes this will enable him to get more farm produce to sell.

loans.name: Mwangaza Group

texts.en:
Mwamikazi is the leader of Mwangaza Group (far left) and is a borrower in Uvira, Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. She is requesting this new loan to increase her stock of fresh fish to sell. Located on the shores of Lake Tanganyika, it is the perfect location to buy fish direct from the fishermen to sell at the market.

With her profits, she hopes to improve her children's lives by continuing to pay for their education.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish for sale.

loans.name: Las Amistosas Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LAS AMISTOSAS”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Urcos, perteneciente a la provincia de Quispicanchis y departamento de Cusco

La socia es la Sra. Pilar ella es conviviente y tiene 34 años y tiene 2 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de tienda de abarrotes y restaurant, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, leche y galletas, la socia por medio de este negocio quiere salir adelante, la socia es una mujer emprendedora y trabajadora, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azúcar, leche y galletas.
Las socias que esta pegadas a la foto grupal se les tomo la foto despues de la reunion porque pidieron permiso por motivos de trabajo.
 
 
 Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de animales, negocio de verduras, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de restaurant.
texts.en:
The members belong to the communal bank “Las Amistosas” (“The Friendly Ones”). This bank is located in the district of Urcos, which belong to the province of Quispicanchis and the department of Cusco.

One member is Mrs. Pilar. She is in a relationship, is 34 years old, and has 2 children. She works in her grocery store and restaurant business. She sells needed products, such as rice, sugar, milk, and cookies. Through this business, she wants to go forward. She is an enterprising and hard-working woman. Her dream is to grow the grocery store business. 

She requests the loan to buy rice, sugar, milk, and cookies.

The members in the attached photo to the left side of the group photo, took the picture after the meeting because they asked permission to skip the meeting because of their work.

The other members are dedicated to a business selling animals, a vegetable business, a grocery store business, and a restaurant business.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk, and cookies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy feeds for her dairy cows, enabling her to produce more milk to sell and make more income to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Andino Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “ANDINO”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Silvia Carolina ella es casada y tiene 50 años y tiene 3 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de venta de productos de belleza, la socia vende lápiz labiales, cremas y perfumes, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m,la socia por medio de este negocio quiere sacar adelante a sus hijos,la socia es una mujer emprendedora y trabajadora que por medio de este negocio quiere sacar adelante a su familia, la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los productos de belleza. La socia solicita le crédito para comprar cremas, lápiz labiales y perfumes.
La socia que esta pegada a la foto grupal se le tomo la foto despues de la reunion porque pidio permiso por motivos de trabajo.

Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de internet, negocio de venta de ropa, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de librería.



La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The ANDINO community bank is in Cusco, a district in the Peruvian "departamento" of Cusco.  

Our member, Sra. Silvia Carolina, is 50-years old.  She is married and has 3 children.  She operates a business selling beauty products: lipstick, creams and perfumes.  She works from 8:00am to 7:00pm.  The business is her means of helping her children get ahead in the world.  Sra. Silvia Carolina is an enterprising woman and started the business to help her family.  She has operated the business for several years and says that it is successful.  For the future, she hopes to open a shop of her own.  For now, she is applying for a loan that she will use to buy lipstick, creams and perfumes that she will resell to her customers.  

The member in the small photo at the bottom left of the larger photo asked to be excused from the group picture because she had to work.  

The group's members have all kinds of businesses: Internet services, clothing sales, corner groceries, and school supply sales.  

Sra. Silvia Carolina is grateful to everyone who has made this form of credit possible and is committed to repaying your loan in the agreed-upon time.

loans.use: to stock her cosmetics sales business.

loans.name: 2 De Enero Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “2 DE ENERO”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Santa Ana, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Olga Hilda ella es casada y tiene 50 años y tiene 5 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azucar, leche y galletas, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 5 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azucar, leche y galletas.

Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de agricultura, negocio de venta de ropa, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de comida.



La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The 2 DE ENERO community bank meets in Santa Ana, a district in the Peruvian "departamento" of Cusco.

Our member, Sra. Olga Hilda is 50 years old.  She is married and has 5 children.  She has a grocery store where she sells everyday products: rice, sugar, milk, snacks, etc.  She works from 8:00am to 7:00pm.  She started the business 5 years ago and says that it is successful.  For the future, she would like to expand the store.  For now, she is applying for a loan that she will use to buy rice, sugar, milk and snacks that she will resell to her customers. 

The members of the group have all kinds of businesses: farms, clothing sales, corner groceries, and food sales.  

Sra. Olga Hilda is grateful to everyone who has made this form of credit possible and is committed to repaying your loans in the agreed-upon time.

loans.use: to stock her grocery business.

loans.name: Marcia Maria

texts.es: María es un señora que vive con bajos recursos económicos, ella esta casada y tiene 6 hijos, María vive con su esposo que es jornalero y con 2 hijos que estan estudiando ya que los 4 son independientes y viven aparte. María vive en el campo y se dedica al jornal y a la crianza de ganado, entre ellos mayormente se dedica a comprar vacas ya que por medio del ordeño y la venta  de leche es asi como se puede ayudar en los gastos de alimentación y educación de sus hijos. María solicita el dinero del crédito para invertirlo en la compra de una vaca. Lo que María aspira es mejorar su negocio mediante la  venta de leche y que no le haga el dinero para que sus hijos sigan estudiando.
texts.en:
María is a lady who lives with few economic resources. She is married and has 6 children. María lives with her husband, who is a day laborer, and 2 children who are studying since the 4 others are independent and live apart. 

María lives in the country and makes a living from day laboring and breeding livestock. Among the two she mostly makes a living purchasing cows since by means milking them and selling the milk she can help with the food and education expenses of her children. 

María is requesting the money of the loan to invest in the purchase of a cow. María aspires to improving her business by selling milk and that she makes the money necessary for her children to continue studying.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Husein

texts.en:
Husein is a 41-year-old married father of two children. He has been employed in a private company in the storage department since 2008, with a part-time job at the police department, where he is responsible for the mailing department.

Husein's limited monthly incomes are barely enough to cover his family's living needs. Thus, for this reason, he is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to pay for his children’s school tuition fees.

Husein hopes to provide his children with a brighter future.

loans.use: to pay for his children's school tuition fees.

loans.name: Mirzogufron

texts.ru:
Мирзогуфрон молодой сварщик города Худжанд. Он занимается сварщиком. У нее есть точка для работы. Мирзогуфрон соединяет металлических частей разрушенных автошины путем сплавления. Он хорошо справляется со своей работой. Он имеет постоянную работу. Мирзогуфрон продвигает свою работу уже 4 года. 
Мирзогуфрон в городе проживает вместе матерью, женой и детьми. Его жена домохозяйка, сидя дома занимается шитьем женской одежды. Она тоже старается помочь Мирзогуфрону обеспечить семью.  Мирзогуфрон хочет приобрести новый электросварочный аппарат  для расширения деятельности. Это аппарат стоит дорого, у Мирзогуфрон не такое количество сумма денег. И он просит кредит для купли необходимый средств.
texts.en:
Mirzogufron is a young welder from the town of Khujand. He has a place to work. Mirzogufron joins the metal parts of broken car wheels by fusing them together. He is good at his job. He has steady work. Mirzogufron has been doing this work for four years.

Mirzogufron lives in the town together with his mother, wife and children. His wife is a homemaker, staying at home and sewing women's clothes. She also tries to help Mirzogufron provide for the family. Mirzogufron wants to buy a new arc welder to expand his business. This piece of equipment is expensive, and Mirzogufron does not have such a sum of money. He is asking for a loan to buy the necessary equipment.

loans.use: to buy an arc welder.

loans.name: Las Flores De Tambocorral Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “LAS FLORES DE TAMBOCORRAL”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Santa Teresa, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Hilaria ella es soltera y tiene 52 años y tiene 2 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de venta de cereales, la socia vende maíz, trigo y quinua, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 5:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 4 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los cereales. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar trigo, maíz y quinua.

Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de animales, negocio de venta de ropa, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de comida.



La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members belong to the “LAS FLORES DE TAMBOCORRAL” [The Flowers of Tambocorral] community bank. This bank is located in the Santa Teresa district, belonging to the La Convención province and the department of Cusco.

The member's name is Hilaria. She is single, is 52 years old, and has 2 children. She works in her grain sales business. She sells corn, wheat, and quinoa, from 8:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. She has had this business for 4 years, and it is going very well for her. Hilaria's dream is to have a store where she can sell the grains.

Hilaria is applying for the loan to buy wheat, corn, and quinoa. The other members make their living in animal sales, clothing sales, grocery store, and food sales.

Hilaria is grateful to all those who are part of this dream through this loan, and is committed to making her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy wheat, corn, and quinoa.

loans.name: Jose Agustin
